segment.source: Learn how to navigate in a basic two page peer-to-peer Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: Learn how to navigate in a basic two page peer-to-peer Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: two-page peer-to-peer navigation example
segment.target: two-page peer-to-peer navigation example

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Frame
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Controls.Frame

segment.source: Create the blank app
segment.target: Create the blank app

segment.source: On the Microsoft Visual Studio menu, choose File New Project.
segment.target: On the Microsoft Visual Studio menu, choose File New Project.

segment.source: In the left pane of the New Project dialog box, choose the Visual C# - Windows - Universal or the Visual C++ - Windows - Universal node.
segment.target: In the left pane of the New Project dialog box, choose the Visual C# - Windows - Universal or the Visual C++ - Windows - Universal node.

segment.source: In the center pane, choose Blank App.
segment.target: In the center pane, choose Blank App.

segment.source: In the Name box, enter NavApp1, and then choose the OK button.
segment.target: In the Name box, enter NavApp1, and then choose the OK button.

segment.source: The solution is created and the project files appear in Solution Explorer.
segment.target: The solution is created and the project files appear in Solution Explorer.

segment.source: Important When you run Visual Studio for the first time, it prompts you to obtain a developer license.
segment.target: Important When you run Visual Studio for the first time, it prompts you to obtain a developer license.

segment.source: For more info, see Enable your device for development.
segment.target: For more info, see Enable your device for development.

segment.source: To run the program, choose Debug Start Debugging from the menu, or press F5.
segment.target: To run the program, choose Debug Start Debugging from the menu, or press F5.

segment.source: A blank page is displayed.
segment.target: A blank page is displayed.

segment.source: Press Shift+F5 to stop debugging and return to Visual Studio.
segment.target: Press Shift+F5 to stop debugging and return to Visual Studio.

segment.source: Add basic pages
segment.target: Add basic pages

segment.source: Next, add two content pages to the project.
segment.target: Next, add two content pages to the project.

segment.source: Do the following steps two times to add two pages to navigate between.
segment.target: Do the following steps two times to add two pages to navigate between.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the BlankApp project node to open the shortcut menu.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the BlankApp project node to open the shortcut menu.

segment.source: Choose Add New Item from the shortcut menu.
segment.target: Choose Add New Item from the shortcut menu.

segment.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, choose Blank Page in the middle pane.
segment.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, choose Blank Page in the middle pane.

segment.source: In the Name box, enter Page1 (or Page2) and press the Add button.
segment.target: In the Name box, enter Page1 (or Page2) and press the Add button.

segment.source: These files should now be listed as part of your NavApp1 project.
segment.target: These files should now be listed as part of your NavApp1 project.

segment.source: Functions are declared in the header (.h) file and implemented in the code-behind file (.cpp).
segment.target: Functions are declared in the header (.h) file and implemented in the code-behind file (.cpp).

segment.source: Add the following content to the UI of Page1.xaml.
segment.target: Add the following content to the UI of Page1.xaml.

segment.source: Add a TextBlock element named as a child element of the root Grid.
segment.target: Add a TextBlock element named as a child element of the root Grid.

segment.source: Change the Text property to .
segment.target: Change the Text property to .

segment.source: Add the following HyperlinkButton element as a child element of the root Grid and after the TextBlock element.
segment.target: Add the following HyperlinkButton element as a child element of the root Grid and after the TextBlock element.

segment.source: Add the following code to the class in the Page1.xaml code-behind file to handle the event of the HyperlinkButton you added previously.
segment.target: Add the following code to the class in the Page1.xaml code-behind file to handle the event of the HyperlinkButton you added previously.

segment.source: Here, we navigate to Page2.xaml.
segment.target: Here, we navigate to Page2.xaml.

segment.source: Make the following changes to the UI of Page2.xaml.
segment.target: Make the following changes to the UI of Page2.xaml.

segment.source: Add a TextBlock element named as a child element of the root Grid.
segment.target: Add a TextBlock element named as a child element of the root Grid.

segment.source: Change the value of the Text property to .
segment.target: Change the value of the Text property to .

segment.source: Add the following HyperlinkButton element as a child element of the root Grid and after the TextBlock element.
segment.target: Add the following HyperlinkButton element as a child element of the root Grid and after the TextBlock element.

segment.source: Add the following code to the class in the Page2.xaml code-behind file to handle the event of the HyperlinkButton you added previously.
segment.target: Add the following code to the class in the Page2.xaml code-behind file to handle the event of the HyperlinkButton you added previously.

segment.source: Here, we navigate to Page1.xaml.
segment.target: Here, we navigate to Page1.xaml.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For C++ projects, you must add a directive in the header file of each page that references another page.
segment.target: For C++ projects, you must add a directive in the header file of each page that references another page.

segment.source: For the inter-page navigation example presented here, page1.xaml.h file contains , in turn, page2.xaml.h contains .
segment.target: For the inter-page navigation example presented here, page1.xaml.h file contains , in turn, page2.xaml.h contains .

segment.source: Now that we've prepared the content pages, we need to make Page1.xaml display when the app starts.
segment.target: Now that we've prepared the content pages, we need to make Page1.xaml display when the app starts.

segment.source: Open the app.xaml code-behind file and change the handler.
segment.target: Open the app.xaml code-behind file and change the handler.

segment.source: Here, we specify in the call to Frame.Navigate instead of .
segment.target: Here, we specify in the call to Frame.Navigate instead of .

segment.source: Note The code here uses the return value of Navigate to throw an app exception if the navigation to the app's initial window frame fails.
segment.target: Note The code here uses the return value of Navigate to throw an app exception if the navigation to the app's initial window frame fails.

segment.source: When Navigate returns true, the navigation happens.
segment.target: When Navigate returns true, the navigation happens.

segment.source: Now, build and run the app.
segment.target: Now, build and run the app.

segment.source: Click the link that says "Click to go to page 2".
segment.target: Click the link that says "Click to go to page 2".

segment.source: The second page that says "Page 2" at the top should be loaded and displayed in the frame.
segment.target: The second page that says "Page 2" at the top should be loaded and displayed in the frame.

segment.source: Frame and Page classes
segment.target: Frame and Page classes

segment.source: Before we add more functionality to our app, let's look at how the pages we added provide navigation support for the app.
segment.target: Before we add more functionality to our app, let's look at how the pages we added provide navigation support for the app.

segment.source: First, a Frame () is created for the app in the method of the App.xaml code-behind file.
segment.target: First, a Frame () is created for the app in the method of the App.xaml code-behind file.

segment.source: The Navigate method is used to display content in this Frame.
segment.target: The Navigate method is used to display content in this Frame.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The Frame class supports various navigation methods such as Navigate, GoBack, and GoForward, and properties such as BackStack, ForwardStack, and BackStackDepth.
segment.target: The Frame class supports various navigation methods such as Navigate, GoBack, and GoForward, and properties such as BackStack, ForwardStack, and BackStackDepth.

segment.source: In our example, is passed to the Navigate method.
segment.target: In our example, is passed to the Navigate method.

segment.source: This method sets the content of the app's current window to the Frame and loads the content of the page you specify into the Frame (Page1.xaml in our example, or MainPage.xaml, by default).
segment.target: This method sets the content of the app's current window to the Frame and loads the content of the page you specify into the Frame (Page1.xaml in our example, or MainPage.xaml, by default).

segment.source: is a subclass of the Page class.
segment.target: is a subclass of the Page class.

segment.source: The Page class has a read-only Frame property that gets the Frame containing the Page.
segment.target: The Page class has a read-only Frame property that gets the Frame containing the Page.

segment.source: When the Click event handler of the HyperlinkButton calls, the Frame in the app's window displays the content of Page2.xaml.
segment.target: When the Click event handler of the HyperlinkButton calls, the Frame in the app's window displays the content of Page2.xaml.

segment.source: Whenever a page is loaded into the frame, that page is added as a PageStackEntry to the BackStack or ForwardStack of the Frame.
segment.target: Whenever a page is loaded into the frame, that page is added as a PageStackEntry to the BackStack or ForwardStack of the Frame.

segment.source: Pass information between pages
segment.target: Pass information between pages

segment.source: Our app navigates between two pages, but it really doesn't do anything interesting yet.
segment.target: Our app navigates between two pages, but it really doesn't do anything interesting yet.

segment.source: Often, when an app has multiple pages, the pages need to share information.
segment.target: Often, when an app has multiple pages, the pages need to share information.

segment.source: Let's pass some information from the first page to the second page.
segment.target: Let's pass some information from the first page to the second page.

segment.source: In Page1.xaml, replace the the HyperlinkButton you added earlier with the following StackPanel.
segment.target: In Page1.xaml, replace the the HyperlinkButton you added earlier with the following StackPanel.

segment.source: Here, we add a TextBlock label and a TextBox () for entering a text string.
segment.target: Here, we add a TextBlock label and a TextBox () for entering a text string.

segment.source: In the event handler of the Page1.xaml code-behind file, add a parameter referencing the property of the TextBox to the method.
segment.target: In the event handler of the Page1.xaml code-behind file, add a parameter referencing the property of the TextBox to the method.

segment.source: In the Page2.xaml code-behind file, override the method with the following:
segment.target: In the Page2.xaml code-behind file, override the method with the following:

segment.source: Run the app, type your name in the text box, and then click the link that says Click to go to page 2.
segment.target: Run the app, type your name in the text box, and then click the link that says Click to go to page 2.

segment.source: When you called in the Click event of the HyperlinkButton, the property was passed to and the value from the event data is used for the message displayed on the page.
segment.target: When you called in the Click event of the HyperlinkButton, the property was passed to and the value from the event data is used for the message displayed on the page.

segment.source: Cache a page
segment.target: Cache a page

segment.source: Page content and state is not cached by default, you must enable it in each page of your app.
segment.target: Page content and state is not cached by default, you must enable it in each page of your app.

segment.source: In our basic peer-to-peer example, there is no back button (we demonstrate back navigation in Back button navigation), but if you did click a back button on , the TextBox (and any other field) on would be set to its default state.
segment.target: In our basic peer-to-peer example, there is no back button (we demonstrate back navigation in Back button navigation), but if you did click a back button on , the TextBox (and any other field) on would be set to its default state.

segment.source: One way to work around this is to use the NavigationCacheMode property to specify that a page be added to the frame's page cache.
segment.target: One way to work around this is to use the NavigationCacheMode property to specify that a page be added to the frame's page cache.

segment.source: In the constructor of , set NavigationCacheMode to Enabled.
segment.target: In the constructor of , set NavigationCacheMode to Enabled.

segment.source: This retains all content and state values for the page until the page cache for the frame is exceeded.
segment.target: This retains all content and state values for the page until the page cache for the frame is exceeded.

segment.source: Set NavigationCacheMode to Required if you want to ignore cache size limits for the frame.
segment.target: Set NavigationCacheMode to Required if you want to ignore cache size limits for the frame.

segment.source: However, cache size limits might be crucial, depending on the memory limits of a device.
segment.target: However, cache size limits might be crucial, depending on the memory limits of a device.

segment.source: Note The CacheSize property specifies the number of pages in the navigation history that can be cached for the frame.
segment.target: Note The CacheSize property specifies the number of pages in the navigation history that can be cached for the frame.
